choices.A: enabled by default on all VLANs and interfaces
choices.C: sends frames with unknown destinations to a multicast group
choices.B: increases security on the management VLAN
choices.D: inspects and drops frames from unknown destinations

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Among the given options:

A. enabled by default on all VLANs and interfaces

This statement is the most accurate regarding MAC learning. MAC learning is a fundamental function of Layer 2 switches and is enabled by default on all interfaces. When a switch receives frames on its interfaces, it learns the source MAC addresses and associates them with the corresponding interface.

So, the corrected and accurate statement would be:

A. enabled by default on all VLANs and interfaces

comments.content: It can't be D because Switches don't drop frames. instead, it floods them to learn the location of devices associated with unknown MAC addresses.

choices.B: tracks the number of active TCP connections
choices.C: offers one collision domain for all connected devices
choices.A: provides a single broadcast domain for all connected devices
choices.D: makes forwarding decisions based on MAC addresses

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If the question A woud be "provides a single broadcast domain for all connected devices in one specific VLAN" than it would be A. Otherwise the main function of a switch is to forward frames based on the MAC-Address

Selected Answer: D
Layer 2 switches forward frames based on MAC addresses at the Data Link layer.
Incorrect options:

A: Switches provide separate collision domains, but only one broadcast domain unless VLANs are used.
B: Tracking TCP connections is a Layer 4 function.
C: Switches create separate collision domains for each port.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

A is incorrect, it provides a single broadcast domain for a specific VLAN not for all connected devices

Selected Answer: D
I would go with D - for me it is more accurate.

Option A - when you use VLANs, you have more broadcast domains

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

comments.content: Layer 2 switch creates multiple collision domain but provides one broadcast domain. Makes forwarding decision using MAC address table not mac address.

discussion.content:
D. makes forwarding decisions based on MAC addresses

Explanation:

A Layer 2 switch operates at the data link layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model. One of its primary functions is to make forwarding decisions based on the MAC (Media Access Control) addresses of devices. When a switch receives a frame, it examines the destination MAC address in the frame and forwards the frame only to the port where the destination device is located. This process is known as switching, and it helps in reducing collisions and improving the efficiency of network communication.

The other options are not accurate descriptions of Layer 2 switch characteristics:

A. Layer 2 switches typically create separate broadcast domains for each connected port, which can help in minimizing unnecessary broadcast traffic.

B. Tracking the number of active TCP connections is typically a function associated with Layer 4 devices such as routers and firewalls, not Layer 2 switches.

C. Layer 2 switches create separate collision domains for each connected device, helping to reduce the likelihood of collisions compared to shared network segments.

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of a Layer 2 switch?

SIMULATION
-


Guidelines
-

This is a lab item in which tasks will be performed on virtual devices.

• Refer to the Tasks tab to view the tasks for this lab item.
• Refer to the Topology tab to access the device console(s) and perform the tasks.
• Console access is available for all required devices by clicking the device icon or using the tab(s) above the console window.
• All necessary preconfigurations have been applied.
• Do not change the enable password or hostname for any device.
• Save your configurations to NVRAM before moving to the next item.
• Click Next at the bottom of the screen to submit this lab and move to the next question.
• When Next is clicked, the lab doses and cannot be reopened.


Topology
-

//IMG//



Tasks
-

VLANS 35 and 45 have been configured in all three switches. All physical connectivity has been installed and verified All inter-switch links must be operational.

1. Configure SW-1 and SW-2 switch ports e0/0 and e0/1 for 802.1q trunking allowing all VLANS
2. Configure the inter-switch links on SW-1 e0/2, SW-2 e0/2, and SW-3 e0/0 and e0/1 to use native VLAN 35
3. Configure SW-1 and SW-2 switch ports e0/0 and e0/1 for link aggregation SW-1 should immediately negotiate LACP and SW-2 must only respond to LACP requests

//IMG//

comments.content:
Looks good!

IMO Task 2 is ambiguous. It asks to configure the inter-switch links "to use native VLAN 35", but doesn't specify anything further. I assume they want a trunk, but an access port in VLAN 35 would work fine assuming no other VLAN traffic needed to be carried.

If you get this error message when entering the "switchport mode trunk" command...
"Command rejected: An interface whose trunk encapsulation is "Auto" can not be configured to "trunk" mode." It is because when the trunk encapsulation is set to "Auto," the switch automatically negotiates the encapsulation type with the connected device. However, if you want to manually set the interface to trunk mode, you need to explicitly specify the trunk encapsulation type.

If the current encapsulation is set to "Auto," you can change it to a specific encapsulation type, such as "dot1q" (802.1Q), using the following commands:
Switch(config-if)# switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q
Switch(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
